column1: Highland Park has earned a reputation for having some of the most expensive property prices in the Dallas area. The median home value in Highland Park is $1
The Highland Park Town Hall houses municipal services. The first floor houses the general administrative offices
column2: the Building Inspection Department
column4: and the Utility Billing and Customer Service Department. The second floor houses the Town Council Chambers
column6: and Municipal Court. The Spanish Colonial architecture building was designed by architects Otto Lang and Frank Witchell. The Highland Park Department of Public Safety and the Highland Park Public Library are adjacent to the town hall.

column1: The town council authorized the purchasing of a fire engine and the construction of a fire house after the 1913 incorporation. The town hall was built in 1924. During the same year
column2: a new fire station opened next to town hall. As time passed
column3: the town hall received several renovations. One connected the town hall to the public safety building. In 2003 a portion of the public safety building was razed
column4: and a new facility was built in its place.Highland Park employs a public safety department instead of separate police and fire/EMS departments.  The public safety officers are certified as firefighters
column6: and paramedics.  They work 24-hour shifts (with the next two days off)
column7: varying their role during the shift. EMS medical direction is provided by the BioTel system through UT-Southwestern Medical School
column8: which provides this service to the majority of fire/EMS departments in Dallas County.

column1: Public primary and secondary schools in Highland Park are operated by either the Highland Park Independent School District or the Dallas Independent School District.

Most of the city (areas east of Roland Avenue) is served by the Highland Park Independent School District (HPISD). The HPISD portion is served by McCulloch Middle School and Highland Park Middle School
column2: which share a campus located partially in Highland Park and partially in University Park.Two elementary schools in Highland Park

column1: A portion of Highland Park (areas west of Roland Avenue) is zoned to Dallas Independent School District. The area is within Trustee District 2 As of 2008 Jack Lowe represents the district. DISD schools that serve western Highland Park include Maple Lawn Elementary School
column2: Rusk Middle School
column3: and North Dallas High School.Prior to fall 2006
column6: and W. T. White High School served western Highland Park. After fall 2006 western Highland Park was rezoned to the schools that serve it as of 2008.

column1: The Highland Park Public Library is adjacent to the Highland Park Town Hall. The library building and art gallery first opened in 1930. As time passed
column2: the art gallery was repurposed as town council chambers and a portion of the library. In 2008 the library underwent major renovations.
